content.raw: I see. I believe the problem is due to anti-aliasing applied to the camera sensor images. This setting is currently fixed. Unfortunately I can't think of an easy way to change it through plugins or sdf.  However, if you're using gazebo compiled from source, you can change [this line of code in Camera.cc](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/14a3e6e94163602588f6965f6123f4f777e2e302/gazebo/rendering/Camera.cc?fileviewer=file-view-default#Camera.cc-1494) and set `fsaa` to 0.
content.html: I see. I believe the problem is due to anti-aliasing applied to the camera sensor images. This setting is currently fixed. Unfortunately I can't think of an easy way to change it through plugins or sdf. However, if you're using gazebo compiled from source, you can change this line of code in Camera.cc and set fsaa to 0.

content.raw:
Thanks for helping. I actually set the background to green (0 1 0 0) so that I can segment the object easily afterwards. My problem is that pixels in the edges of the object become someway interpolated with the background and therefore turn greenish (a color which was chosen precisely because it is not in the model). Would it be possible to render in a way so that pixels corresponding to the object are not affected by the background? I am providing a sample image. Thank you!

 ![image.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/88506700-image.png)
content.html: Thanks for helping. I actually set the background to green (0 1 0 0) so that I can segment the object easily afterwards. My problem is that pixels in the edges of the object become someway interpolated with the background and therefore turn greenish (a color which was chosen precisely because it is not in the model). Would it be possible to render in a way so that pixels corresponding to the object are not affected by the background? I am providing a sample image. Thank you!

content.raw: hi, not sure if I understand your question. The background color you're referring to is the gray ground plane and gray background in the scene? Do you have a screenshot to illustrate what you mean?
content.html: hi, not sure if I understand your question. The background color you're referring to is the gray ground plane and gray background in the scene? Do you have a screenshot to illustrate what you mean?

content.raw: Hey, I am trying to find the answer to a related topic. Where can I disable the edge interpolation happening between a model and the background color? Thank you.
content.html: Hey, I am trying to find the answer to a related topic. Where can I disable the edge interpolation happening between a model and the background color? Thank you.

content.raw: It's already `static`, I just didn't see that. Looks fine to me now. Thank to @iche033 for helping me read.
content.html: It's already static, I just didn't see that. Looks fine to me now. Thank to @iche033 for helping me read.

content.raw: It could easily be changed to `const` or `static` though since it doesn't touch any member variables?
content.html: It could easily be changed to const or static though since it doesn't touch any member variables?

content.raw: I will leave it as it is for now
content.html: I will leave it as it is for now

content.raw: You make the call, and I'll approve it
content.html: You make the call, and I'll approve it

content.raw: It works for me too. I'm ready to push the button when the last Steve's comments are addressed.
content.html: It works for me too. I'm ready to push the button when the last Steve's comments are addressed.

content.raw: Testing it again right now.
content.html: Testing it again right now.

content.raw:
it should probably just be `static`, as it doesn't touch any class member variables. 

I think having data structure would be nice but I want to keep the API easier to use for now, and if in the future we decide to support different distortion models, we can start implementing different `DistortionData` classes which store different params/coefficients.
content.html:
it should probably just be static, as it doesn't touch any class member variables.

I think having data structure would be nice but I want to keep the API easier to use for now, and if in the future we decide to support different distortion models, we can start implementing different DistortionData classes which store different params/coefficients.

content.html: I think this is the last unaddressed comment
